subsection.title: Properties of the identity matrix
subsection.p: Here are some important facts about the identity matrix and inverses of matrices. You could consider this proposition as a continuation of .

proposition.title: Algebra rules involving the identity matrix

statement.p:
Let I represent the n\times n identity matrix.
For every m\times n matrix A and every n\times k matrix B, we have AI = A and IB = B.
For every positive integer p, we have I^p = I.
\inv{I} = I.
\utrans{I} = I.

proof.p: We will leave the proof of these properties up to you, the reader.

subsection.title: Properties of the inverse
subsection.p: And now some first properties of the inverse. We will explore inverses more in the next chapter.

statement.p: A square matrix is either singular or has one unique inverse.
A square zero matrix is always singular.

proof.p:

subsection.p: Let's record the formula for 2\times 2 inverses that we encountered in .

statement.p:
Consider general 2\times 2 matrix A = \left[\begin{smallmatrix} a \amp b\\c \amp d \end{smallmatrix}\right]. If ad-bc\neq 0, then A is invertible with inverse
\inv{A} = \frac{1}{ad-bc}\;\left[\begin{array}{rr} d \amp -b\\-c \amp a \end{array}\right].

proof.title: Proof idea
proof.p: You can check by direct computation that these two matrices multiply to the identity matrix, in either order.

aside.title: A look ahead
aside.p: We will further explore the formula ad-bc and its connection to invertibility of matrices in subsequent chapters.

subsection.p: Here are the properties of inverses we explored in . We have changed some of the letters to avoid confusion with the A and B in the definition of inverse in .

ol.li: If M is an invertible square matrix, then its inverse \inv{M} is also invertible with inverse \inv{(\inv{M})} = M.
If M is an invertible square matrix, then for every nonzero scalar k the scalar multiple kM is also invertible with inverse \inv{(kM)} = \inv{k}\inv{M}.
If M and N are both invertible square matrices of the same size, then their product MN is also invertible with inverse \inv{(MN)} = \inv{N}\inv{M}.

If M_1,M_2,\dotsc,M_{\ell-1},M_\ell are all invertible square matrices of the same size, then their product M_1 M_2 \dotsm M_{\ell-1} M_\ell is also invertible with inverse \inv{(M_1 M_2 \dotsm M_{\ell-1} M_\ell)} = \inv{M}_\ell \inv{M}_{\ell-1}\dotsm\inv{M}_2\inv{M}_1.
If M is an invertible square matrix, then for every positive integer \ell the power M^\ell is also invertible with inverse \inv{(M^\ell)} = (\inv{M})^\ell.

We have a square matrix A=\inv{M} and would like to find an inverse B for it, so that both BA=I and AB=I are true. But we already know this is true for B = M, since then
BA \amp= M\inv{M} = I, \amp \amp\text{and} \amp AB \amp= \inv{M}M = I.

li.p:
We have a square matrix A = kM, with k\neq 0, and would like to find an inverse B for it. Let's try B = \inv{k}\inv{M}:
BA \amp= (\inv{k}\inv{M})(kM) \amp AB \amp= (kM)(\inv{k}\inv{M})
\amp = (\inv{k}k)(\inv{M}M) \amp \amp = (k\inv{k})(M\inv{M})
\amp = 1I \amp \amp = 1I
\amp = I, \amp \amp = I,
where in the first steps we have applied Rule and Rule of .
Since both BA=I and AB=I are true, then B=\inv{k}\inv{M} is the inverse of A=kM.
Since both BA=I and AB=I are true, then B=\inv{N}\inv{M} is the inverse of A=MN.

remark.p: In light of Statement of the proposition, for an invertible matrix M and a positive integer k we can write M^{-k} to mean either the inverse \inv{(M^k)} or the power (\inv{M})^k, since they are the same. This answers the question in Activity.

subsection.p: We can turn some of the statements of around to create new facts about singular ( non-invertible) matrices.

ol.li: If the product MN is singular, where M and N are square matrices of the same size, then at least one of M,N must be singular.
If the product M_1 M_2 \dotsm M_{\ell-1} M_\ell is singular, where M_1,M_2,\dotsc,M_{\ell-1},M_\ell are square matrices of all the same size, then at least one of these matrices must be singular.
If some power M^\ell is singular, where M is a square matrix and \ell is a positive integer, then M must be singular.

If both M and N were invertible, then Statement of says that the product MN would be invertible. But we are assuming that the product MN is singular, so it is not possible for both M and N to be invertible.

statement.p: If A is invertible, then so is \utrans{A}, with \inv{(\utrans{A})} = \utrans{(\inv{A})}.

proposition.title: Algebra involving matrix powers with negative exponents

statement.p:
With the convention that A^0 should be equal to I for any invertible square matrix A, the matrix algebra rules involving matrix powers in
(including the property of the transpose relative to powers in rule Rule) and in
remain valid for all integers p and q, positive or negative (or zero).

subsection.p: Finally, we will record the observation of .

statement.p: If the coefficient matrix for a linear system is square and invertible, then the system has one unique solution.

proof.p:
Consider system A\uvec{x}=\uvec{b} where the coefficient matrix A is square and invertible. Then we can apply \inv{A} to both sides of this matrix equation just as in
and in , to isolate \uvec{x}=\inv{A}\uvec{b}. Thus, \uvec{x} = \inv{A}\uvec{b} is the only possible solution to the system.

aside.title: A look ahead
aside.p: It follows from a fact in the next chapter () that the logic of goes the other way as well: if a system with a square coefficient matrix has one unique solution, then that coefficient matrix must be invertible.
